title: Lesson 34 – When & If; Kailan, Nun, Kapag & Kung

contents.markdown: In this lesson we will cover “when” as a question word and as “during”. We will also talk a bit about “if”.
<u>When as a Question Word: Kailan</u>
_Kailan_ is an interrogative, or question word, which is used to ask “when?”:
**Kailan** + Phrase? (Tag) = When Phrase? (Eng)

item.tagalog: Kailan siya nag-aral?
item.english: When did she study?

item.tagalog: Kailan masaya si Jason?
item.english: When is Jason happy?

item.tagalog: Kailan ka natutulog?
item.english: When do you sleep?

contents.markdown: <u>When as During</u>
There are several words used for “when” as in “during”. We will discuss the most common ones. Here is a breakdown of how they are used:
nun past actions
kapag non-past actions
habang	past and non-past actions
kung non-past actions
<u>Nun</u>
As mentioned before, _nun_ is used for past actions:
Phrase + nung + phrase. (Tag) = Phrase during period. (Eng)
**Note: _Nung_ is just _nun_+ linker. For past actions.**

item.tagalog: Gusto ni Joe ng pizza nung naglaro siya.
item.english: Joe wanted pizza when he played.

item.tagalog: Nasa Maynila siya nung bata pa siya.
item.english: She was in Manila when she was still young.

item.tagalog: Tinanong ako ni Maria nung ginawa niya ang adobo.
item.english: Maria asked me when she made the adobo.

contents.markdown: As used above, _nung_ means “when”. Remember that _nung_+ adv is used for past actions, and roughly means “last”, “in” or “on”.

item.tagalog: Gusto ni Joe ng pizza nung Martes.
item.english: Joe wanted pizza last Tuesday.

item.tagalog: Pumunta si Jasmine sa Cebu nung 2001.
item.english: Jasmine went to Cebu in 2001.

item.tagalog: Kinuha nila ang mga mangga nung ikatlo ng Marso.
item.english: They got the mangoes on the 3rd of March.

contents.markdown: <u>Kapag</u>
_Kapag_ has a less common short form _pag_, and is used with non-past actions.
Phrase + kapag + phrase. (Tag) = Phrase when phrase. (Eng)
**Note: For non-past actions.**

item.tagalog: Kakain ako kapag nasa sasakyan ako.
item.english: I will eat when I am in the car.

item.tagalog: Binubuksan ba ni Maria ang pinto kapag nag-aaral siya?
item.english: Does Maria open the door when she studies?

item.tagalog: Maganda siya kapag natutulog siya.
item.english: She is pretty when she sleeps.

contents.markdown: <u>Habang</u>
_Habang_ is used for both past and non-past actions.
Phrase + habang + phrase. (Tag) = Phrase when phrase. (Eng)

item.tagalog: Kakain ako habang nasa sasakyan ako.
item.english: I will eat when I am in the car.

item.tagalog: Maganda siya habang natutulog siya.
item.english: She is pretty when she sleeps.

item.tagalog: Binigyan kita nito habang nasa Maynila siya.
item.english: I gave it to you when he was in Manila.

contents.markdown: _Habang_ may seem easier because it works for all periods, and it is quite common. But _nun_ is a more common for past actions and _kapag_ is a more common for non-past actions, so we will not use _habang_ any more in this book.
<u>Kung as If</u>

_Kung_ is interchangeable with _kapag_, and they are both used for non-past actions. Both can also mean “if”, but it is more common to use _kung_ as “if” and _kapag_ as “during”, so that is how we will use them.
Phrase + kung + phrase. (Tag) = Phrase if phrase. (Eng)
**Note: For non-past actions.**

item.tagalog: Kakain ako kung nasa sasakyan ako.
item.english: I will eat if I am in the car.

item.tagalog: Binubuksan ba ni Maria ang pinto kung mag-aaral siya?
item.english: Does Maria open the door if she were to study?

item.tagalog: Maganda siya kung natutulog siya.
item.english: She is pretty if she sleeps.

contents.markdown: <u>Kung + Question Word</u>
Sometimes we want to use a question word in a sentence, but the sentence is not a question. In these cases, put _kung_ before the question word.
Phrase + kung + question word + phrase. (Tag) = Phrase question word phrase. (Eng)

item.tagalog: Nagluto sila kung saan ako kumain ng pizza.
item.english: They cooked where I ate pizza.

item.tagalog: Makikita ni Joe kung sino ang guro.
item.english: Joe will see who the teacher is.

item.tagalog: Binibiro niya ako kung magkano ang mga mangga.
item.english: She is kidding me about how much the mangoes are.

contents.markdown: <u>Phrase Order</u>
As you will see later, _nun, kapag_ and _kung_(if) are actually conjunctions, or words that join two phrases. Like in English, the phrases can optionally be reversed, with the conjunction in front:

item.tagalog: Nung naglaro siya, gusto ni Joe ng pizza.
item.english: When he played, Joe wanted pizza.

item.tagalog: Kapag nasa sasakyan ako, kakain ako.
item.english: When I am in the car, I will eat.

item.tagalog: Kung natutulog siya, maganda siya.
item.english: If she sleeps, she is pretty.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kailan mo masasabi sa kaniya ang totoo?
exampleSentences.english: When will you be able to tell her the truth?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nung hinanap siya ni Joshua, wala siya sa bisikleta.
exampleSentences.english: When Joshua looked for her, she was not on the bicycle.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Iinumin ko lang ang tubig kung kakainin ko ang lechon.
exampleSentences.english: I will only drink the water if I eat the lechon.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Masaya si Angel kapag sinasagot niya ang mga mahihirap na tanong.
exampleSentences.english: Angel is happy when she is answering the difficult questions.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Tinatanong ka ni Maria kung ilang taon ka na.
exampleSentences.english: Maria is asking you how old you are.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kailan niluto ng asawa mo ang pagkain?
exampleSentences.english: When did your wife cook the food?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kung hindi mo ako binibiro, sundin mo na ang pangulo.
exampleSentences.english: If you are not kidding me, obey the president already.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Opo. Nandito po ang CR nung Marso, di ba?
exampleSentences.english: Yes. (resp.) The restroom was here in March, wasn't it? (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nasaan ka kapag tatawagin mo ako nang alas-onse y medya ng gabi?
exampleSentences.english: Where will you be when you call out to me at 11:30pm?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nagsabi si Diego kung magkano ang tsokolate.
exampleSentences.english: Diego said how much the chocolate was.
